THE TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE SUBPROJECT 
A.  Overall Progress of the TA cluster 
1.  The $20.22 million technical assistance Cluster (C–TA) 0013–INO for the Sustainable 
Infrastructure Assistance Program (SIAP) is financed by the Government of Australia through the 
Department of Foreign Affairs and Trade, and administered by the Asian Development Bank 
(ADB).  SIAP was approved on 17 June 2013 and is due to close on 30 June 2019. SIAP provides 
infrastructure preparation and delivery support for ADB’s program in Indonesia and is classified 
as a multisector TA. The outcome is to improve project readiness and develop projects in the 
energy, transport, water supply and sanitation and urban services sectors. It delivers this through: 
(i) policy and advisory services; (ii) capacity building of sector agencies; (iii) project preparation 
support; and (iv) knowledge sharing. 
 
2.  As of 21 August 2018, total approvals are $17,797,510 (88% of total funds against time 
elapsed of 86%), and disbursements are $9,134,294 (51% of subproject approvals). Fifteen 
subprojects have been approved. Four of these are now closed. SIAP is on track to meet its 
outcome and outputs, including the preparation and implementation of approved ADB projects 
and programs in Indonesia of more than $5 billion. As of 21 August 2018, C–TA 0013–INO: SIAP 
has  an  available  balance  of  $1,645,683,  including  the  ADB  management  fee  and  foreign 
exchange reservations. 
 
B.  Subproject Outcome 
3.  Rationale. Inadequate infrastructure, due in large part to underinvestment in the past, is 
a  key  constraint  to  higher  and  more  inclusive  growth  in  Indonesia.  Recognizing  this,  the 
government  has  embarked  on  an  ambitious  infrastructure  development  agenda comprising 
significant increases in public sector spending for infrastructure, as well as policy and institutional 
reforms to create an enabling environment for public-private partnerships (PPPs) and private 
sector investment more generally. Central and local government infrastructure spending rose by 
1%  of  GDP  to  2.7%  between  2014  and  2017.  However,  the  annual  expenditure  of  
$23 billion falls short of the estimated annual investment needs of $70 billion (before climate 
change adjustment). As of March 2018, 10 PPP projects with an aggregate cost of $7.8 billion 
were under construction, while 33 PPP projects valued at $4.2 billion were being tendered. While 
improving, the private sector thus does not yet play a meaningful role in Indonesia’s infrastructure 
development. 
4.  In response, the government has recently initiated a number of measures aimed at 
developing  innovative  infrastructure  financing  mechanisms.  Among  its  main  priorities  is  to 
improve financing options for municipalities to address infrastructure gaps at the subnational level.  
To this end, the government is establishing Indonesia’s first municipal bond issuance program. In 
addition to helping raise funds for infrastructure and other development expenditures, this initiative 
to  facilitate  provinces’  entry  into  capital  markets  will  also  help  promote  fiscal  prudence, 
transparency in financial reporting, and accountability to investors.  Another priority initiative is 
the introduction of new infrastructure financing products in support of private sector investment in 
infrastructure  through  the  state-owned  infrastructure  financing  company,  PT  Sarana  Multi 
Infrastruktur (PT SMI). Specifically, PT SMI is considering options to provide takeout finance1 and 
                                                
1  Takeout finance is offered to individual lenders to infrastructure project companies typically after commercial 
operations date (COD); it replaces a percentage of the residual amount of their loans with longer tenor financing and 
addresses the asset-liability mismatch resulting from short-term PPP infrastructure debt financing.

2 
credit enhancement products aimed at increasing the tenor of the loan from existing lenders and 
improving the credit rating of loans or project bonds thereby catalyzing institutional investment.  
 
5.   Previous and existing initiatives.  The TA subproject builds on and complements ADB’s 
support of infrastructure finance, including the establishment of the Indonesia Infrastructure 
Guarantee Fund (IIGF), which provides government guarantees to infrastructure projects, and 
Indonesia Infrastructure Facility (IIF),2 which invests in infrastructure through the private sector.  In 
addition, in 2013, ADB worked with West Java provincial government to prepare for municipal 
bond issuance and was able to secure an above-investment grade shadow rating. Soon after, 
DKI Jakarta collaborated with the World Bank on the same initiative and secured a AA- shadow 
rating with Standard & Poor’s.  However, these efforts did not advance to actual issuance at the 
time due to readiness issues associated with the change in local government leadership.    
 
6.   Addressing  funding  gaps  at  the  subnational  (SNG)  level.  Following  extensive 
consultations – 5 provinces were under consideration to pilot the municipal “pemda” bond 
issuance program – DKI Jakarta (supported under SIAP Phase I) and Central Java (supported 
under SIAP Phase II) were selected based on the strength of their balance sheets, liquidity, 
profitability and viable project portfolios. DKI Jakarta is currently targeting Q2 2019 and Central 
Java Q1 2020 for their first municipal bond issuance, subject to approval by their respective City 
Councils. Both provinces are expected to issue general obligation municipal bonds (cf. revenue 
bonds), but the SNGs have decided to include good, viable infrastructure projects in the official 
statement (bond prospectus equivalent for municipal bond issues), to showcase to investors as 
one of the underlying uses of the general obligation municipal bonds. Bond issuance preparatory 
activities for Central Java are already underway with the support of ADB funding and DKI Jakarta 
will follow shortly. The local rating agency, Pefindo, is providing shadow and actual credit rating 
support to Central Java on a complimentary basis in its efforts to support this innovative venture 
in the country. The government has proposed 5, 7 and 10-year3 municipal bonds issued in 
tranches; non-bank financial institutions such as pension funds and insurance companies are the 
would-be investors who currently have the appetite for bonds issued by at least AA-rated (national) 
SNGs. Municipal issuers are required to obtain approval and agreement from the local parliament, 
the Ministry of Finance, Ministry of Home Affairs and OJK4 (the financial services authority). 
Furthermore, funds to pay the coupon and principal amounts due on the outstanding municipal 
bonds must be budgeted by the SNG until the bonds mature. This will be achieved by the selected 
provincial governments by using a sinking fund, which together with the enactment of local law to 
support municipal bonds and underlying projects, must be approved by the local parliament in a 
session chaired by the governor.  
 
7.  Addressing funding gap using innovative financial products. PT SMI is keen to 
establish a takeout finance scheme that has the flexibility to be applied to different sectors, at 
different stages of a typical project finance transaction, and is considering collaborating with 
Mitsubishi Union Financial Group (MUFG) on this initiative. As the largest project financiers in 
Indonesia (and globally), MUFG can only lend in Indonesia for up to 7 years which does not match

the concession periods of about 15–25 years in typical PPP transactions, and would therefore 
welcome the Takeout Finance product. Takeout finance offers an opportunity for existing lenders 
to replace their loans for a fee and subject to specific terms. This in turn  will free up private capital 
which can be invested in more infrastructure projects. PT SMI has intentions to replicate the 
Takeout Finance model used by the India Infrastructure Finance Company Limited (IIFCL), a 
state-owned institution similar to PT SMI.5 After exploring the feasibility and practicability of this 
product through the TA, ADB could consider partnering with PT SMI by providing a credit line to 
on-lend for takeout finance. 
 
8.  PT SMI is considering a second product, a partial credit guarantee (PCG), and has 
identified a toll road project as a pilot. A PCG could be offered by PT SMI to lenders and investors, 
for a fee, to de-risk PPP loans or project bonds by providing first-loss cover (of up to 50% for 
example) in the event of debt service default by the project special purpose vehicle (SPV). By 
utilizing this credit enhancement, a higher credit rating and lower pricing will be assigned to the 
debt instrument thereby decreasing financing costs, extending maturities beyond prevailing 
market terms in the country, and catalyzing institutional investors such as pension funds and 
insurance companies. PCG will increase availability of finance and stimulate the market by 
introducing a new class of instruments. ADB could consider partnering with PT SMI and share its 
credit risk exposure to underlying projects by providing a portion of the guarantee payout.6  
 
9.  In order to explore the breadth of innovative financing opportunities in the country through 
which ADB may partner with the government for lending, this project will also provide capacity 
building and technical expertise support to IIF and IIGF as described in the terms of reference in 
the linked documents. 
 
10.  At the government’s request, the proposed subproject will provide technical advice and 
capacity building support to help establish the municipal bond issuance program and develop new 
financial products through PT SMI. The project is aligned with government strategies and with the 
priorities of the ADB country partnership strategy 2016–2019 for Indonesia7 and complements 
ongoing and planned support for infrastructure development.  The project will help achieve 
sustainable development goal 9. The subproject is consistent with and supports ADB’s Strategy 
2030. Increased infrastructure financing and mobilization of private sector investment will support 
the  government’s  efforts  to:  (i)  make  cities  more  livable;  (ii)  strengthen  governance  and 
institutional capacity; and (iii) address remaining poverty and reduce inequalities. 
 
11.  The  proposed  subproject  will  have  the  following  outcome:  innovative  infrastructure 
financing facilitated. It also supports the overall SIAP 1 TA cluster outcome of improved project 
readiness and development of a set of bankable projects in the energy, transport, WSS, and urban 
services sectors. The sustainable development goal is to build resilient infrastructure, promote 
inclusive and sustainable industrialization and foster innovation. 
 
12.   Strong government ownership. The government, through the third National Medium-
Term Development Plan, Rencana Pembangunan Jangka Menengah Nasional (RPJMN) 2015–
2019, has a renewed focus on the development of infrastructure with active participation from the 
subnational governments, the central government and SOEs, and the encouragement of private 
sector investment. There has been strong ownership and commitment at the highest level of

C.  Subproject Outputs, Methods, and Activities   
12.  Key activities. ADB will work with the Coordinating Ministry of Economic Affairs (CMEA) 
and  DKI  Jakarta  to  provide  capacity  building  and  technical  expertise  for  the  rating  and 
underwriting processes (shadow rating,8 bond preparatory activities and actual issuance), project 
selection as well as funding the following issuance fees: rating agency, notary and trustee fees 
for the first issuances of the province. ADB will also provide capacity building through pricing, risk 
assessment, structuring, project selection and investor outreach, to help PT SMI achieve its 
planned product launches. 
 
13.  Output 1: Preparatory activities towards Indonesia’s first ever municipal bond 
issuance completed. The credit rating and bond issuance preparatory activities will ensure that 
the  DKI  Jakarta  provincial  government  is  aware  of  capital  markets’  perception  of  their 
creditworthiness by assessing their financial management practices through a comparison of its 
performance to peer provinces. This is critical for the viability of the intended bond issuance and 
the municipal bond market more broadly as accountability to investors and transparency are 
essential. The assistance will ensure that a functioning debt management unit is achieved before 
bond issuance; it will also achieve the following municipal bond issuance activities: (i) pre-launch: 
structuring, appointment of legal counsel and lead managers, legal documentation review and 
due diligence; (ii) launch: draft term sheet, settlement of fees, informing clearing systems and 
listing authority, negotiating the terms of the issue; and (iii) issue: signing and closing. After the 
first “hand-held” issuance, the province is expected to repeat the process independently following 
any lessons learned and actively use bond issuance as a mode of financing infrastructure 
alongside other sources.  
 
14.  Output 2: Municipal funding plan established. The TA will improve the efficiency of the 
investment process with good infrastructure project selection criteria in DKI Jakarta; this is central 
to improving the province’s capacity in capital investment planning and fiscal discipline. Prudent 
underlying project selection will lower risk premiums on municipal bond issues. Other activities 
planned include local parliament approval of legislation enacting the funding plan and a sinking 
fund to support the municipal bond issuance program.  
 
15.  Output 3: Innovative infrastructure financing product strategy adopted. Although PT 
SMI has the resource capacity to structure project and structured finance transactions, it has yet 
to work on the proposed takeout finance and PCG products, therefore would need capacity 
building for structuring and project selection for new and operational infrastructure projects in its 
portfolio.  These  include:  (i)  establishing  a  fee-pricing  mechanism;  (ii)  product  structuring;  
(iii) preparation of draft whitepapers to introduce pilot credit-enhancement products to the market; 
(iv)  project  identification;  (v)  investor  outreach;  (vi)  risk  assessment  methodology;  and  
(vii) benchmarking with similar institutions in India like IIFCL and Infrastructure Development 
Finance  Company  Ltd  (IDFC).  Similar  support  to  explore  a  range  of  innovative  financing 
instruments will be extended to IIF and IIGF. This subproject also supports all outputs of the 
overall SIAP 1 TA Cluster: (i) policy and advisory services; (ii) capacity development of relevant 
government agencies; (iii) preparation of bankable infrastructure projects; and (iv) knowledge 
management and dissemination. 
                                                
8  Shadow rating refers to an unofficial rating process without a public announcement. It serves as a guide to the issuing 
entity on the actual process and to perceive how an intended debt issuance might be received by the market.

D.  Subproject Cost and Financing 
 
16.  The TA subproject is estimated to cost $557,000 of which $530,000 will be financed on a 
grant basis by the Government of Australia. The government will provide support in the form of 
counterpart staff, review of outputs, office space, workshop and consultation support, and other 
in-kind contributions. ADB will cover only a portion of issuance fees for first issuances and the 
province will cover the rest. The cost estimates9 and financing plan are in the table in Appendix 
3.  
 
E.  Subproject Implementation Arrangements 
17.  The Public Management, Financial Sector and Trade Division (SEPF) of the Southeast 
Asia Department will manage the subproject in close coordination with IRM. SEPF will select, 
supervise, and evaluate consultants and arrange for payment of issuance fees. CMEA will be the 
executing agency. CMEA, and PT SMI, IIGF and IIF will be the implementing agencies.

19.  Payment of a portion of total issuance fees.  In order to support the selected provinces 
for the country’s inaugural municipal bond issuance program, ADB will bear a portion of the 
issuance fees payable to the respective counterparts using the following selection procedures:11 
(i) Rating agency fees for the bond instrument: there are only 2 qualified rating agencies in 
Indonesia registered with OJK (Otoritas Jasa Keuangan). They will be invited to submit a 
quotation and ADB will sign an agreement with the selected agency; (ii) Legal counsel fees12 likely 
through competitive selection; and (iii) Notary and Trustee fees: they are standardized and there 
is no room for price competition. ADB and the executing agency may choose a notary and trustee 
based on the EA’s experience using the service providers, in particular past performance and 
their availability. The service providers will satisfy the requirements of ADB Procurement Policy 
(2017,  as  amended  from  time  to  time)  and  the  associated  Project  Administration
